s.text: Indeed, if you read the official reports of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, that's the way they portray things.
Britain was vulnerable to speculators in 1992, because there was a sound, if not universally accepted, economic case for devaluation.
Nor are the Russian banks that have just crashed really banks in the Western sense of the word.

So in a sense all the Russian government needs to pay its bills is for those seven men, plus a fringe of smaller-scale oligarchs who would surely follow their lead, to pay the necessary taxes.
But in fact the money quickly disappeared, as speculators--certainly including the oligarchs themselves--converted rubles into dollars as fast as the dollars became available.

The essence of the financial crisis that has rocked the world in the last few weeks is this: Investors, which means anyone with money at stake, appear to have decided, once and for all, that the men who run Russia are not only corrupt but shortsightedly so--that they are looters rather than kleptocrats.
